skill.name: changelog-generator
skill.description: Automatically creates user-facing changelogs from git commits by analyzing commit history, categorizing changes, and transforming technical commits into clear, customer-friendly release notes. Turns hours of manual changelog writing into minutes of automated generation.
skill.summary: Transforms git commits into polished, user-friendly changelogs with categorized changes and professional formatting
skill.author: DYAI2025

security_audit.summary: This skill is safe for publication. The static analyzer detected external command patterns, but these are false positives from markdown code fence examples showing user prompts, not actual executable code. The skill is purely instructional documentation with no scripts or executable files. No legitimate security risks were identified.

content.user_title: Generate User-Friendly Changelogs from Git Commits
content.value_statement: Manual changelog writing is time-consuming and inconsistent, especially when translating technical commits into customer-friendly language. This skill automatically analyzes your git history, categorizes changes, and generates polished release notes that users can actually understand.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes git commit history from specified date ranges or version tags
Categorizes commits into features, improvements, bug fixes, breaking changes, and security updates
Translates technical commit messages into clear, customer-friendly language
Filters out internal commits like refactoring, tests, and development tasks
Generates professionally formatted changelog entries following best practices
Supports custom changelog style guidelines from your documentation
limitations: Requires access to a git repository with commit history
Quality depends on the clarity and detail of original commit messages
May need manual review to ensure accuracy and appropriate tone
Cannot automatically determine breaking changes without proper commit conventions

use_cases.title: Release Notes for Product Launch
use_cases.description: Generate customer-facing release notes when shipping a new version. Transform technical commits into compelling feature announcements and fix descriptions that highlight value to users.

use_cases.title: Weekly Development Updates
use_cases.description: Create weekly or monthly summaries of development progress for stakeholders. Automatically compile what changed, what improved, and what was fixed in an easily digestible format.

use_cases.title: App Store Update Descriptions
use_cases.description: Generate update descriptions for app store submissions. Convert git history into concise, marketing-friendly text that explains new features and improvements to potential users.

best_practices: Run this skill from your git repository root directory to ensure proper access to commit history
Specify clear date ranges or version tags for focused, relevant changelogs rather than entire project history
Review and adjust the generated changelog before publishing to ensure accuracy and appropriate messaging for your audience
anti_patterns: Do not use this skill on repositories with poorly written commit messages expecting perfect output without manual review
Avoid generating changelogs without specifying a date range or version, as this may include too much irrelevant history
Do not publish auto-generated changelogs directly without reviewing for sensitive information or inappropriate technical details

faq.question: Does this skill require any external tools or dependencies?
faq.answer: The skill works with Claude Code and requires access to a git repository. It uses git commands to analyze commit history, which are standard tools already available in most development environments.

faq.question: Can I customize the format and style of the generated changelog?
faq.answer: Yes, you can reference your own changelog style guide document when invoking the skill. It will adapt the output to match your specified formatting, tone, and categorization preferences.

faq.question: How does the skill categorize commits into different sections?
faq.answer: The skill analyzes commit messages and changes to automatically group them into categories like features, improvements, bug fixes, breaking changes, and security updates. It uses semantic understanding of the commit content rather than relying solely on commit message conventions.

faq.question: Will this skill include internal development commits in the changelog?
faq.answer: No, the skill automatically filters out internal commits such as refactoring, test updates, build changes, and other development tasks that are not relevant to end users. It focuses on user-facing changes.

faq.question: Can I use this for generating changelogs in languages other than English?
faq.answer: Yes, Claude supports multiple languages. You can specify your desired output language in your prompt, and the skill will generate the changelog in that language while translating technical terms appropriately.

faq.question: How accurate is the translation from technical commits to user-friendly language?
faq.answer: The quality depends on your original commit messages. Clear, descriptive commits produce better changelogs. You should always review the output before publishing to ensure accuracy and adjust any descriptions that need clarification or better positioning.
